elements.content: We report the synthesis of novel heterobimetallic precursors of the formula [RE­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ [RE = Y, Gd; Hhfa = 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione; tetraglyme = 2,5,8,11,14-pentaoxapentadecane], which can be efficiently used as a single source for the metal–organic chemical vapor deposition of NaREF4 films.
elements.clean_text: We report the synthesis of novel heterobimetallic precursors of the formula [RE(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ [RE = Y, Gd; Hhfa = 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione; tetraglyme = 2,5,8,11,14-pentaoxapentadecane], which can be efficiently used as a single source for the metal-organic chemical vapor deposition of NaREF4 films.

elements.content: A one-pot synthesis of binuclear Na-RE (RE = Y, Gd) complexes is reported. The synthesized compounds act as a metal−organic chemical vapor deposition single source for all of the different elements required to fabricate NaREF4 films.
elements.clean_text: A one-pot synthesis of binuclear Na-RE (RE = Y, Gd) complexes is reported. The synthesized compounds act as a metal-organic chemical vapor deposition single source for all of the different elements required to fabricate NaREF4 films.

elements.content: During the past few years, sodium rare-earth (RE) tetrafluorides (NaREF4; RE = Gd, Y, Lu) have been reported to be ideal matrixes for upconversion (UC) processes when doped with Ln3+ ions such as Yb3+/Er3+ (Tm3+, Ho3+). NaREF4 exists in two polymorphic forms at ambient pressure and temperature: cubic (α) and hexagonal (β), with the latter phase being the most efficient host matrix for UC emission.
elements.clean_text: During the past few years, sodium rare-earth (RE) tetrafluorides (NaREF4; RE = Gd, Y, Lu) have been reported to be ideal matrixes for upconversion (UC) processes when doped with Ln3+ ions such as Yb3+/Er3+ (Tm3+, Ho3+). NaREF4 exists in two polymorphic forms at ambient pressure and temperature: cubic (α) and hexagonal (β), with the latter phase being the most efficient host matrix for UC emission.

elements.content: Up to now, great effort has been made in the synthesis and application of NaREF4 crystals or powders suitably doped for UC applications. In particular, hydro- and solvothermal methods have been applied.
elements.clean_text: Up to now, great effort has been made in the synthesis and application of NaREF4 crystals or powders suitably doped for UC applications. In particular, hydro- and solvothermal methods have been applied.

elements.content: However, photonic applications require the UC materials to be in thin-film form, but so far the fabrication of NaYF4 and NaGdF4 materials in thin-film form has been scarcely investigated. In particular, electrodeposition, thermal evaporation, and sol–gel/spin-coating approaches have been applied to synthesize UC NaYF4 and/or NaGdF4 films.
elements.clean_text: However, photonic applications require the UC materials to be in thin-film form, but so far the fabrication of NaYF4 and NaGdF4 materials in thin-film form has been scarcely investigated. In particular, electrodeposition, thermal evaporation, and sol-gel/spin-coating approaches have been applied to synthesize UC NaYF4 and/or NaGdF4 films.

elements.content: Nevertheless, a simpler and straightforward process easily scalable in view of potential industrial applications is highly desirable. Compared to physical vapor deposition techniques, metal–organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) is advantagous, especially for complex phases such as the ternary phases of these NaREF4 systems, because of its simple process, ready scalability, and higher throughput.
elements.clean_text: Nevertheless, a simpler and straightforward process easily scalable in view of potential industrial applications is highly desirable. Compared to physical vapor deposition techniques, metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) is advantagous, especially for complex phases such as the ternary phases of these NaREF4 systems, because of its simple process, ready scalability, and higher throughput.

elements.content: From the perspective of the synthesis of multicomponent films, the availability of suitable precursors is of crucial importance. In conventional MOCVD, the metal sources of multimetal films, such as NaREF4, must be not only thermally stable but also compatible in terms of volatility to easily adjust the film stoichiometry. Thus, the availability of a single-source heterometallic precursor containing all of the required elements (Na, RE, and F) in a single molecule is highly desirable because it would not only ensure greater homogeneity at atomic levels and the absence of unnecessary contaminating ions but also allow better control of the process.
elements.clean_text: From the perspective of the synthesis of multicomponent films, the availability of suitable precursors is of crucial importance. In conventional MOCVD, the metal sources of multimetal films, such as NaREF4, must be not only thermally stable but also compatible in terms of volatility to easily adjust the film stoichiometry. Thus, the availability of a single-source heterometallic precursor containing all of the required elements (Na, RE, and F) in a single molecule is highly desirable because it would not only ensure greater homogeneity at atomic levels and the absence of unnecessary contaminating ions but also allow better control of the process.

elements.content: Recently, some heterobimetallic complexes containing sodium and rare-earth metals have been synthesized and applied to the fabrication of NaREF4 nanomaterials via solution or decomposition routes. In a few cases, their thermal behavior makes them potentially applicable to MOCVD processes because quantitative sublimation was observed in an evacuated, sealed ampule at 150 °C for 24 h.
elements.clean_text: Recently, some heterobimetallic complexes containing sodium and rare-earth metals have been synthesized and applied to the fabrication of NaREF4 nanomaterials via solution or decomposition routes. In a few cases, their thermal behavior makes them potentially applicable to MOCVD processes because quantitative sublimation was observed in an evacuated, sealed ampule at 150 °C for 24 h.

elements.content: In this Communication, we report, for the first time, the synthesis and comprehensive investigation [single-crystal X-ray structure, NMR and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) characterization, and thermal behavior] of novel single-source heterobimetallic precursors of the formula [RE­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ [RE = Y (1), Gd (2)]. Their potential as a MOCVD source has been assessed through their applications to the deposition of NaREF4 films. The final results indicate these adducts as new-generation precursors of MOCVD processes. In fact, they present better behavior versus the “first-generation” precursors, i.e., simple β-diketonates, which are not very stable, leading to problems of reproducibility, and the “second-generation” ones, i.e., polyether β-diketonate adducts, which are volatile and thermally stable but supply only one metal ion. Overall, these “third-generation” precursors are volatile thermally stable and simultaneously supply all of the elements required for the target phase, namely, two metal ions and fluorine.
elements.clean_text: In this Communication, we report, for the first time, the synthesis and comprehensive investigation [single-crystal X-ray structure, NMR and Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) characterization, and thermal behavior] of novel single-source heterobimetallic precursors of the formula [RE(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ [RE = Y (1), Gd (2)]. Their potential as a MOCVD source has been assessed through their applications to the deposition of NaREF4 films. The final results indicate these adducts as new-generation precursors of MOCVD processes. In fact, they present better behavior versus the "first-generation" precursors, i.e., simple β-diketonates, which are not very stable, leading to problems of reproducibility, and the "second-generation" ones, i.e., polyether β-diketonate adducts, which are volatile and thermally stable but supply only one metal ion. Overall, these "third-generation" precursors are volatile thermally stable and simultaneously supply all of the elements required for the target phase, namely, two metal ions and fluorine.

elements.content: The [RE­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ adducts have been prepared through a one-pot reaction of a rare-earth (Y, Gd) nitrate source, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hexafluoroacetylacetone (Hhfa), and tetraglyme in dichloromethane (). RE ( NO 3 ) 3 · 6 H 2 O + 4 Hhfa + 4 NaOH + tetraglyme → [ RE ( hfa ) 4 ] − [ Na · tetraglyme ] + + 10 H 2 O + 3 NaNO 3
elements.clean_text: The [RE(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ adducts have been prepared through a one-pot reaction of a rare-earth (Y, Gd) nitrate source, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hexafluoroacetylacetone (Hhfa), and tetraglyme in dichloromethane (). 1    RE   (   NO   3   )   3   ⋅ 6   H   2   O + 4 Hhfa + 4 NaOH + tetraglyme →   [ RE   ( hfa )   4   ]   -     [ Na ⋅ tetraglyme ]   +   + 10   H   2   O + 3   NaNO   3

elements.content: The reaction was conducted in a single step under simple laboratory conditions. In particular, the RE­(NO3)3·6H2O was first suspended in dichloromethane. Tetraglyme was added to the suspension. NaOH and Hhfa were added after 10 min, and the mixture was refluxed under stirring for 1 h. Colorless crystals were obtained after partial evaporation of the solvent. The crystals were collected, washed with pentane, filtered, and dried under vacuum.
elements.clean_text: The reaction was conducted in a single step under simple laboratory conditions. In particular, the RE(NO3)3⋅6H2O was first suspended in dichloromethane. Tetraglyme was added to the suspension. NaOH and Hhfa were added after 10 min, and the mixture was refluxed under stirring for 1 h. Colorless crystals were obtained after partial evaporation of the solvent. The crystals were collected, washed with pentane, filtered, and dried under vacuum.

elements.content: A slight excess of NaOH (10%) was used in both cases. NaOH exerts a double effect: it serves as a base able to deprotonate the acidic hydrogen of Hhfa, and it is the source of the sodium ion. This procedure yields reproducibly, under open-bench manipulations, a clean source adduct in high yield. It has a very low melting point and evaporates quantitatively at low temperature under vacuum and even under atmospheric pressure.
elements.clean_text: A slight excess of NaOH (10%) was used in both cases. NaOH exerts a double effect: it serves as a base able to deprotonate the acidic hydrogen of Hhfa, and it is the source of the sodium ion. This procedure yields reproducibly, under open-bench manipulations, a clean source adduct in high yield. It has a very low melting point and evaporates quantitatively at low temperature under vacuum and even under atmospheric pressure.

elements.content: The FT-IR transmittance spectra of complexes 1 and 2 (Figure S1) show the absence of any band around 3500 cm–1, usually due to OH stretching, thus indicating the anhydrous nature of the complexes. For adduct 1, the peaks at 1657, 1557, and 1530 cm–1 are associated with the CO and CC stretching vibrations, typical of the β-diketonate framework. Peaks observed in the 1000–1300 cm–1 range are characteristic of the polyether C–O bending and/or stretching overlapped with the C–F stretching features. In addition, the glyme modes appear at 949, 852, and 796 cm–1. IR data for adduct 2 are commented on in the Supporting Information (SI). The FT-IR hypothesis, i.e., the anhydrous nature of the two complexes, was confirmed by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis performed on 1 and 2. In the asymmetric unit of the two compounds (which are isomorphous and isostructural), just one [Na·tetraglyme]+ cation and one [RE­(hfa)4]− anion (RE = Y and Gd in 1 and 2, respectively) are present. The RE cations (YIII in 1 and GdIII in 2) are octacoordinated by the oxygen atoms of four hfa anions (Table S2). The resulting coordination polyhedron is a distorted bicapped trigonal prism with the oxygen atoms O4 and O8 capping the O1–O2–O3–O6 and O2–O5–O6–O7 faces, respectively (see and S5 and S6 for the atom labeling). The sodium cation is coordinated by the five oxygen atoms of one tetraglyme molecule and by two fluorine atoms of two different hfa anions ( and Table S2). The resulting coordination polyhedron may be described as a pentagonal bipyramid, with the five oxygen atoms defining the base. Because of the coordination around the sodium cation (one fluorine atom belongs to a symmetry-related hfa anion), a 1D chain polymer, which propagates along the a–c diagonal, arises (Figure S7). A similar propensity to form a chain polymer has already been observed in two other salts (CSD refcodes = CYSFAC10 and EQUXOF) having [Y­(hfa)4]− as the anion and an alkaline metal as the cation (cesium and sodium in CYSFAC10 and EQUXOD, respectively), although in these previous cases, because of the absence of ancillary ligands (as in our structures the tetraglyme molecule), coordination of the alkaline cation is completed by the donor atoms (oxygen and/or fluorine atoms) of the hfa anion, and this forces the RE and alkaline metal to stay closer (Figures S8 and S9). In fact, in CYSFAC10, the Y···alkaline metal shortest distance is about 4.5 Å, while it is 3.7 Å in EQUXOF. In 1 and 2, the Y···Na shortest distances are 6.632(5) and 6.600(7) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The FT-IR transmittance spectra of complexes 1 and 2 (Figure S1) show the absence of any band around 3500 cm-1, usually due to OH stretching, thus indicating the anhydrous nature of the complexes. For adduct 1, the peaks at 1657, 1557, and 1530 cm-1 are associated with the CO and CC stretching vibrations, typical of the β-diketonate framework. Peaks observed in the 1000-1300 cm-1 range are characteristic of the polyether C-O bending and/or stretching overlapped with the C-F stretching features. In addition, the glyme modes appear at 949, 852, and 796 cm-1. IR data for adduct 2 are commented on in the Supporting Information (SI). The FT-IR hypothesis, i.e., the anhydrous nature of the two complexes, was confirmed by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis performed on 1 and 2. In the asymmetric unit of the two compounds (which are isomorphous and isostructural), just one [Na⋅tetraglyme]+ cation and one [RE(hfa)4]- anion (RE = Y and Gd in 1 and 2, respectively) are present. The RE cations (YIII in 1 and GdIII in 2) are octacoordinated by the oxygen atoms of four hfa anions (Table S2). The resulting coordination polyhedron is a distorted bicapped trigonal prism with the oxygen atoms O4 and O8 capping the O1-O2-O3-O6 and O2-O5-O6-O7 faces, respectively (see  and S5 and S6 for the atom labeling). The sodium cation is coordinated by the five oxygen atoms of one tetraglyme molecule and by two fluorine atoms of two different hfa anions ( and Table S2). The resulting coordination polyhedron may be described as a pentagonal bipyramid, with the five oxygen atoms defining the base. Because of the coordination around the sodium cation (one fluorine atom belongs to a symmetry-related hfa anion), a 1D chain polymer, which propagates along the a-c diagonal, arises (Figure S7). A similar propensity to form a chain polymer has already been observed in two other salts (CSD refcodes = CYSFAC10 and EQUXOF) having [Y(hfa)4]- as the anion and an alkaline metal as the cation (cesium and sodium in CYSFAC10 and EQUXOD, respectively), although in these previous cases, because of the absence of ancillary ligands (as in our structures the tetraglyme molecule), coordination of the alkaline cation is completed by the donor atoms (oxygen and/or fluorine atoms) of the hfa anion, and this forces the RE and alkaline metal to stay closer (Figures S8 and S9). In fact, in CYSFAC10, the Y⋅⋅⋅alkaline metal shortest distance is about 4.5 Å, while it is 3.7 Å in EQUXOF. In 1 and 2, the Y⋅⋅⋅Na shortest distances are 6.632(5) and 6.600(7) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Ellipsoid displacement view of the [Y­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ complex. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity. Just one model for the tetraglyme molecule and for the fluorine atoms of the hfa anions is reported (see the SI).
elements.clean_text: 1  Ellipsoid displacement view of the [Y(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ complex. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity. Just one model for the tetraglyme molecule and for the fluorine atoms of the hfa anions is reported (see the SI).

elements.content: The study of the thermal properties of the [Y­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ and [Gd­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ adducts is a crucial step for the successful application of these precursors to MOCVD processes. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of the 1 and 2 derivatives have been carried out at atmospheric pressure under a purified nitrogen flow. The TG curve of the adduct 1, reported in , indicates that the β-diketonate adduct evaporates almost quantitatively in the 180–300 °C temperature range, with a low residue (≈8%) at 350 °C, thus indicating clean vaporization of the precursor. The derivative curve of TG (DTG) consists of a single peak, which confirms that complex evaporation occurs in a single step, without any side decomposition.
elements.clean_text: The study of the thermal properties of the [Y(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ and [Gd(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ adducts is a crucial step for the successful application of these precursors to MOCVD processes. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of the 1 and 2 derivatives have been carried out at atmospheric pressure under a purified nitrogen flow. The TG curve of the adduct 1, reported in , indicates that the β-diketonate adduct evaporates almost quantitatively in the 180-300 °C temperature range, with a low residue (~8%) at 350 °C, thus indicating clean vaporization of the precursor. The derivative curve of TG (DTG) consists of a single peak, which confirms that complex evaporation occurs in a single step, without any side decomposition.

elements.content: TG (solid lines) and DTG (dashed lines) curves of complexes 1 and 2 under a nitrogen flow at atmospheric pressure in the 30–400 °C temperature range.
elements.clean_text: 2  TG (solid lines) and DTG (dashed lines) curves of complexes 1 and 2 under a nitrogen flow at atmospheric pressure in the 30-400 °C temperature range.

elements.content: Regarding complex 2 (), the adduct evaporates in a single step in a narrow temperature range (190–290 °C) with a residue of 13% at 350 °C. A single-step evaporation occurs also in this case, as inferred by the single peak of the DTG curve of the adduct.
elements.clean_text: Regarding complex 2 (), the adduct evaporates in a single step in a narrow temperature range (190-290 °C) with a residue of 13% at 350 °C. A single-step evaporation occurs also in this case, as inferred by the single peak of the DTG curve of the adduct.

elements.content: From thermal analysis, we can conclude that both heterobimetallic precursors 1 and 2 show good mass-transport properties, which is a prerequisite for MOCVD applications; thus, they are expected to be suitable precursors for the deposition of Na–Y–F and Na–Gd–F films, respectively.
elements.clean_text: From thermal analysis, we can conclude that both heterobimetallic precursors 1 and 2 show good mass-transport properties, which is a prerequisite for MOCVD applications; thus, they are expected to be suitable precursors for the deposition of Na-Y-F and Na-Gd-F films, respectively.

elements.content: It is motivating to compare the thermal properties of these [RE­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ compounds with its Na­(hfa)­tetraglyme relative, which decomposes upon heating, leaving a residue of NaF. Therefore, yttrium and gadolinium, which are very volatile compounds as single-metal polyether hexafluoroacetylacetonate adducts, act as vehicles for the alkaline sodium ion from the solid to vapor phase.
elements.clean_text: It is motivating to compare the thermal properties of these [RE(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ compounds with its Na(hfa)tetraglyme relative, which decomposes upon heating, leaving a residue of NaF. Therefore, yttrium and gadolinium, which are very volatile compounds as single-metal polyether hexafluoroacetylacetonate adducts, act as vehicles for the alkaline sodium ion from the solid to vapor phase.

elements.content: Hence, validation of the [RE­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ heterobimetallic adducts to act as a single source of Na–RE–F elements has been assessed by applying both complexes to the MOCVD synthesis of sodium–yttrium and sodium–gadolinium fluoride films on silicon substrates (see the SI for experimental details).
elements.clean_text: Hence, validation of the [RE(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ heterobimetallic adducts to act as a single source of Na-RE-F elements has been assessed by applying both complexes to the MOCVD synthesis of sodium-yttrium and sodium-gadolinium fluoride films on silicon substrates (see the SI for experimental details).

elements.content: Film characterization from a structural point of view has been assessed by XRD analysis in a grazing-incidence mode. The XRD pattern of the NaGdF4 film grown at 500 °C nominal deposition temperature (a) shows peaks corresponding to 111, 200, 220, and 311 reflections of the cubic NaGdF4 lattice (ICDD 27-0697). Similarly, the θ–2θ pattern of the NaYF4 film deposited at 500 °C (c) may be associated with the cubic phase of NaYF4 (ICDD 06-0342). The nature of the polymorphic phase formed deserves a comment. In fact, although the α phase is usually the less thermodynamically stable phase, it should be considered that MOCVD is a dynamic process where kinetic factors may compete with the thermodynamic stability of a system. Therefore, it is evident that under the presently applied conditions the kinetic factors are predominant, yielding the α phase.
elements.clean_text: Film characterization from a structural point of view has been assessed by XRD analysis in a grazing-incidence mode. The XRD pattern of the NaGdF4 film grown at 500 °C nominal deposition temperature (a) shows peaks corresponding to 111, 200, 220, and 311 reflections of the cubic NaGdF4 lattice (ICDD 27-0697). Similarly, the θ-2θ pattern of the NaYF4 film deposited at 500 °C (c) may be associated with the cubic phase of NaYF4 (ICDD 06-0342). The nature of the polymorphic phase formed deserves a comment. In fact, although the α phase is usually the less thermodynamically stable phase, it should be considered that MOCVD is a dynamic process where kinetic factors may compete with the thermodynamic stability of a system. Therefore, it is evident that under the presently applied conditions the kinetic factors are predominant, yielding the α phase.

elements.content: XRD pattern (a) and plane-view FE-SEM image (b) of the NaGdF4 film and XRD pattern (c) and plane-view FE-SEM image (d) of the NaYF4 film grown on silicon through MOCVD. S labels indicate peaks of the silicon substrate.
elements.clean_text: 3  XRD pattern (a) and plane-view FE-SEM image (b) of the NaGdF4 film and XRD pattern (c) and plane-view FE-SEM image (d) of the NaYF4 film grown on silicon through MOCVD. S labels indicate peaks of the silicon substrate.

elements.content: In regard to morphology, the field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images of the NaGdF4 samples present homogeneous surfaces with 100 nm grains (b). Analogously, the NaYF4 films show a homogeneous surface with grains having dimensions of 150 nm (d). The root-mean-square roughness, evaluated through atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements (Figure S9) on a 5 μm × 5 μm surface of the NaYF4 film, is about 21 nm.
elements.clean_text: In regard to morphology, the field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images of the NaGdF4 samples present homogeneous surfaces with 100 nm grains (b). Analogously, the NaYF4 films show a homogeneous surface with grains having dimensions of 150 nm (d). The root-mean-square roughness, evaluated through atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements (Figure S9) on a 5 μm × 5 μm surface of the NaYF4 film, is about 21 nm.

elements.content: In regard to the film purity, energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyses point to 0.95:1 and 1:1.06 ratios for the NaYF4 and NaGdF4 stoichiometries, respectively, over a 10 mm × 10 mm area. This information, combined with the XRD data, indicates that no minority or amorphous phases are present.
elements.clean_text: In regard to the film purity, energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyses point to 0.95:1 and 1:1.06 ratios for the NaYF4 and NaGdF4 stoichiometries, respectively, over a 10 mm × 10 mm area. This information, combined with the XRD data, indicates that no minority or amorphous phases are present.

elements.content: In summary, the present study is the first MOCVD synthetic report on the fabrication of NaREF4 films. This challenging goal has been achieved through the use of two novel heterobimetallic [RE­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ adducts, which have been synthesized and successfully applied as single-source precursors for the deposition of NaREF4 thin films through MOCVD processes. The thermal properties of the synthesized precursors point to their optimal characteristics for the MOCVD application in terms of volatility and thermal stability. To our knowledge, these complexes represent the first ever examples of single sources of three different elements, namely, sodium, RE metal, and fluorine, with thermal properties suitable for MOCVD applications, thus going beyond traditional issues related to the use of separated sources. The straightforward one-pot nature of the presently reported synthetic route envisages the possibility of synthesizing novel adducts with new metals, making this approach a wide-ranging strategy for the synthesis of novel MOCVD precursors.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the present study is the first MOCVD synthetic report on the fabrication of NaREF4 films. This challenging goal has been achieved through the use of two novel heterobimetallic [RE(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ adducts, which have been synthesized and successfully applied as single-source precursors for the deposition of NaREF4 thin films through MOCVD processes. The thermal properties of the synthesized precursors point to their optimal characteristics for the MOCVD application in terms of volatility and thermal stability. To our knowledge, these complexes represent the first ever examples of single sources of three different elements, namely, sodium, RE metal, and fluorine, with thermal properties suitable for MOCVD applications, thus going beyond traditional issues related to the use of separated sources. The straightforward one-pot nature of the presently reported synthetic route envisages the possibility of synthesizing novel adducts with new metals, making this approach a wide-ranging strategy for the synthesis of novel MOCVD precursors.

cln_elements.content:
The study of the thermal properties of the [Y­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ and [Gd­(hfa)4]−[Na·tetraglyme]+ adducts is a crucial step for the successful application of these precursors to MOCVD processes. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of the 1 and 2 derivatives have been carried out at atmospheric pressure under a purified nitrogen flow. The TG curve of the adduct 1, reported in , indicates that the β-diketonate adduct evaporates almost quantitatively in the 180–300 °C temperature range, with a low residue (≈8%) at 350 °C, thus indicating clean vaporization of the precursor. The derivative curve of TG (DTG) consists of a single peak, which confirms that complex evaporation occurs in a single step, without any side decomposition.

Regarding complex 2 (), the adduct evaporates in a single step in a narrow temperature range (190–290 °C) with a residue of 13% at 350 °C. A single-step evaporation occurs also in this case, as inferred by the single peak of the DTG curve of the adduct.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The study of the thermal properties of the [Y(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ and [Gd(hfa)4]-[Na⋅tetraglyme]+ adducts is a crucial step for the successful application of these precursors to MOCVD processes. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurements of the 1 and 2 derivatives have been carried out at atmospheric pressure under a purified nitrogen flow. The TG curve of the adduct 1, reported in , indicates that the β-diketonate adduct evaporates almost quantitatively in the 180-300 °C temperature range, with a low residue (~8%) at 350 °C, thus indicating clean vaporization of the precursor. The derivative curve of TG (DTG) consists of a single peak, which confirms that complex evaporation occurs in a single step, without any side decomposition.

Regarding complex 2 (), the adduct evaporates in a single step in a narrow temperature range (190-290 °C) with a residue of 13% at 350 °C. A single-step evaporation occurs also in this case, as inferred by the single peak of the DTG curve of the adduct.

metadata.title:
Heterobimetallic Sodium Rare-Earth Complexes: “Third-Generation”
